measured_by: ventral tegmental area (VTA) dopamine neuron firing
justification: The article states that the key “teaching” signal for reinforcement-learning models "might be instantiated in the firing of ascending dopamine neurons that project from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to the striatum," directly linking VTA dopamine activity to the reward-prediction-error construct.

It notes that "the magnitude of feedback-locked P300 signals, measured via EEG, positively relate to the degree of learning from feedback and track dynamic learning rate adjustments in changing environments," indicating that P300 is used to index moment-to-moment changes in learning rate.

The review reports that "pupil dilations, which positively correlate with learning in tasks with changepoint structures … reflect transient changes in arousal" that modulate how much is learned, tying pupil size measurements to learning-rate dynamics.

It describes that the inferred drift-rate parameter "was related to feedback-locked BOLD response in dorsomedial prefrontal cortex," showing dmPFC fMRI activity as a neural measure of trial-by-trial learning-rate changes.

measured_by: ramping firing rates of LIP/FEF neurons (single-unit recordings)
justification: The article explains that neurons in LIP and FEF "show dynamic activity profiles … that match predictions of evidence accumulation in a drift diffusion model," with firing rates ramping until decision, thereby operationalizing evidence accumulation via single-unit recordings.

For humans, it notes that "correlates of evidence accumulation have been found … in the centroparietal positivity (O'Connell et al., 2012)," identifying the CPP ERP as an electrophysiological marker of the evidence-accumulation process.
